journal-title-group.journal-title: Verfassung und Recht in Übersee / Law and Politics in Africa, Asia and Latin America

publisher.publisher-name: Institut für Internationale Angelegenheiten der Universität Hamburg

title-group.article-title: Mondialisation et insertion internationale de l'Afrique: l'anthropologie d'une dynamique récusée

abstract.p: This paper renews the problem of Africa's international presence, presence which for a long time has been contested by the Path dependence theory in international relations relegating Africa to the periphery of the world linking its destiny to that of the Western World. This thesis is anthropologically and historically erroneous for the simple reason that colonial era is an impertinent sign of Africa's presence in the international scene; rather, a long time before one could enable an objective appropriate restitution of Africa's implication in the world which began even before the colonial era (transsaharian trade, establishment of Indonesian colonies in Madagascar, regular trade with India, the regions of the Persian Golf and the Mediterranean).
